text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 1.4.32.1(5), Program, Scope and Objectives, updated office name from Outreach, Assessment and Reporting to Internal Reviews.
IRM 1.4.32, dated September 26, 2019, is superseded.
All business units
Table of Contents
Retention/Accessibility of Reports
Review Program
page (

) This IRM provides general guidance on the Internal Control Review (ICR) program and the established procedures designed to support the CFO’s to improve the quality of IRS’s internal controls. The ICR program provides business units with insight into the effectiveness of their implemented correc- tive actions for audit recommendations issued by Government Accountability Office (GAO) and TIGTA, which evaluates critical controls over IRS programs which may be high risk, high priority or high visibility. This independent nation assists the business units when they review and evaluate their control processes. (

) Purpose: Internal controls include activities used to monitor processes, dures and programs to ensure they are operating as intended. Effective internal controls are also the ﬁrst line of defense for safeguarding assets, venting and detecting errors and mitigating risk. Internal controls are a vital allowing each manager to evaluate and monitor programs proactively and eliminate deﬁciencies timely. Business unit program managers have the primary responsibility for ensuring effective controls over their speciﬁc programs. The ICR analyst performs reviews to determine if there are any internal control deﬁciencies and provides recommendations to improve or strengthen internal controls. The ICR program assists IRS senior leadership with oversight by providing independent insight into the status of program controls. (
) Audience: IRS managers and employees. (
) Policy Owner: The CFO, Office of Internal Controls (IC), is responsible for IRM. (

) Program Owner: Internal Reviews, Internal Control Review program, knowledge management and sharing of internal controls throughout the Service by reviewing, testing, measuring and reporting on various controls. (

) Primary Stakeholder: This IRM and its related procedures apply to the entire IRS workforce. It is incumbent upon the program owners to evaluate the tiveness of their programs. The term “program” in this IRM includes projects, operations and any supporting activities. (

) Program Goals: The Servicewide ICR program supports ongoing program provements by conducting a thorough analysis of internal controls and identifying potential deﬁciencies. The process is intended to allow ICR to evaluate the way a program works and make recommendations for improve- ments to controls and risk mitigation strategies. This, in turn, allows the program owners to develop and implement process improvements and strengthen controls, thereby eliminating deﬁciencies and mitigating risks a program failure occurs or external stakeholders are adversely affected. All managers have a responsibility to perform periodic monitoring to review accuracy and effectiveness of the internal controls. As required by IRM

, Monitoring and Improving Internal Control, all program managers are respon- sible for ensuring their programs have effective controls in place and for monitoring those controls for continued effectiveness over time. (
) This section clariﬁes ICR’s role throughout the Service:
Internal Control Review Program

) This IRM provides general guidance on the Internal Control Review (ICR) program and the established procedures designed to support the CFO’s efforts and to improve the quality of IRS’s internal controls. The ICR program provides business units with insight into the effectiveness of their implemented correc- tive actions for audit recommendations issued by Government Accountability Office (GAO) and TIGTA, which evaluates critical controls over IRS programs which may be high risk, high priority or high visibility. This independent exami- nation assists the business units when they review and evaluate their internal control processes. (

) Purpose: Internal controls include activities used to monitor processes, proce- dures and programs to ensure they are operating as intended. Effective internal controls are also the ﬁrst line of defense for safeguarding assets, pre- venting and detecting errors and mitigating risk. Internal controls are a vital allowing each manager to evaluate and monitor programs proactively and eliminate deﬁciencies timely. Business unit program managers have the primary responsibility for ensuring effective controls over their speciﬁc programs. The ICR analyst performs reviews to determine if there are any internal control deﬁciencies and provides recommendations to improve or strengthen internal controls. The ICR program assists IRS senior leadership with oversight by providing independent insight into the status of program controls. (
) Audience: IRS managers and employees.
) Audience: IRS managers and employees. (
) Policy Owner: The CFO, Office of Internal Controls (IC), is responsible for this IRM. (

) Program Owner: Internal Reviews, Internal Control Review program, promotes knowledge management and sharing of internal controls throughout the Service by reviewing, testing, measuring and reporting on various controls. (

) Primary Stakeholder: This IRM and its related procedures apply to the entire IRS workforce. It is incumbent upon the program owners to evaluate the effec- tiveness of their programs. The term “program” in this IRM includes processes, projects, operations and any supporting activities. (

) Program Goals: The Servicewide ICR program supports ongoing program im- provements by conducting a thorough analysis of internal controls and identifying potential deﬁciencies. The process is intended to allow ICR to evaluate the way a program works and make recommendations for improve- ments to controls and risk mitigation strategies. This, in turn, allows the program owners to develop and implement process improvements and strengthen controls, thereby eliminating deﬁciencies and mitigating risks before a program failure occurs or external stakeholders are adversely affected.
Program Goals: The Servicewide ICR program supports ongoing program im

provements by conducting a thorough analysis of internal controls and identifying potential deﬁciencies. The process is intended to allow ICR to evaluate the way a program works and make recommendations for improve

ments to controls and risk mitigation strategies. This, in turn, allows the program owners to develop and implement process improvements and strengthen controls, thereby eliminating deﬁciencies and mitigating risks a program failure occurs or external stakeholders are adversely affected.

All managers have a responsibility to perform periodic monitoring to review accuracy and effectiveness of the internal controls. As required by IRM 1.4.2, Monitoring and Improving Internal Control, all program managers are respon- sible for ensuring their programs have effective controls in place and for monitoring those controls for continued effectiveness over time.
1.4 Resource Guide for Managers

Resource Guide for a. The ICR program partners with the business units to identify gaps, ciencies, weaknesses or program concerns and to provide the units with recommendations to improve or strengthen internal controls. b. The ICR analyst applies a variety of methods (for example, administra- tive, analytical or technical) when evaluating and examining a program, procedure or process. c. Once the ICR analyst concludes the review, the Office of Internal Controls will issue to the point of contact (POC) at the relevant unit a report including results, conclusions, recommendations and ﬁndings, if applicable. (
) Federal Manager’s Financial Integrity Act (FMFIA) of
Under
USC Section

(c) and (d) of the FMFIA, federal agencies are required to establish internal control over their accounting and administrative activities and review internal control systems periodically. The FMFIA also requires GAO prescribe internal control standards to serve as criteria for reviews. (
) Standards for Internal Control in the Federal Government (also known as “Green Book”) GAO-

G. The GAO issued Standards for Internal in the Federal Government (Green Book), which provides the overall framework for agencies to establish, maintain and assess internal control agency operations. As part of the monitoring component, the Green Book directs agency personnel to monitor their respective internal control systems, evaluate the results and remediate identiﬁed internal control deﬁciencies (
) Treasury Directive
, Treasury Internal Control Program. Treasury Directive

, Treasury Internal Control Program (TICP) (dated requires bureau heads and other officials to take all necessary steps to an environment within their respective organizations that ensures adherence all applicable statutory and regulatory standards related to operational, ﬁnancial, program and administrative internal controls. This includes assurances to Treasury that the internal controls within their respective zations adhere to applicable statutory and regulatory standards and ensuring timely completion of corrective actions for identiﬁed control deﬁciencies. (
) This section provides responsibilities for: a. CFO and Deputy CFO b. Associate CFO for Internal Controls c. Internal Reviews d. Business units (
) The CFO and Deputy CFO manage a portfolio of enterprise-wide activities including budget formulation, budget execution, accounting, ﬁnancial CFO ment, and internal controls. (

) The Associate CFO for Internal Controls administers the IRS internal program and is responsible for coordinating and executing processes which for assess the completeness and effectiveness of internal controls and support annual assurance and ﬁnancial statement audit activities by: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
E
The ICR program partners with the business units to identify gaps, deﬁ

ciencies, weaknesses or program concerns and to provide the business units with recommendations to improve or strengthen internal controls. The ICR analyst applies a variety of methods (for example, administra

tive, analytical or technical) when evaluating and examining a program, procedure or process. Once the ICR analyst concludes the review, the Office of Internal Controls will issue to the point of contact (POC) at the relevant unit a report including results, conclusions, recommendations and ﬁndings, if applicable.

The Associate CFO for Internal Controls administers the IRS internal controls program and is responsible for coordinating and executing processes which assess the completeness and effectiveness of internal controls and support annual assurance and ﬁnancial statement audit activities by:
Evaluating the effectiveness of internal controls. Partnering with business units to implement and evaluate Office of agement and Budget (OMB) Circular A-

requirements. Developing detailed procedures, documentation, training for managers and employees and reporting requirements necessary to review, establish, maintain, test, improve and report on the IRS’s control systems. Providing advice and assistance to managers and their internal control coordinators.
Internal Reviews’ (IR) staff responsibilities include:

a. Establishing and documenting the ICR program processes, policies and procedures. b. Collecting and analyzing data relevant to the program under review. c. Developing a test plan or a preliminary research memorandum as appro

priate for any review which states the objective, focus areas, related IRM references or external audits, issues identiﬁed and any additional comments important to the review. d. Providing a report outlining the purpose, scope, background analysis, ﬁndings, and conclusions, in addition to any recommendations from the ICR team.

Managers are responsible for improving and strengthening internal Program management responsibility with respect to the ICR program is to: a. Monitor controls with higher risk and greater vulnerabilities. b. Identify subject matter experts (SMEs) for each program, process, or procedure. c. Foster communication and develop a strategy to engage staff by aging the importance of internal controls. d. Track and address open GAO, TIGTA, and Financial Assurance Testing (FACT) audit ﬁndings and recommendations. Managers and SMEs are responsible for: a. Providing documentation to ICR program staff upon request. b. Providing comments on potential ﬁnding within the report. SMEs are responsible for: a. Coordinating timely responses to ICR inquiries via the designated POC. b. Coordinating logistics for ICR team ﬁeld visits. Program reporting includes the following: a. The ICR team develops a post

review report detailing methodology, testing, ﬁndings and recommendations, as appropriate. Internal leadership delivers the report to the owner of the program being reviewed. The report may be provided to external stakeholders under certain circumstances. For example, reports and related materials will provided upon request to TIGTA or GAO; reports may be provided matically where the review is being conducted in conjunction with
Managers are responsible for improving and strengthening internal controls. Program management responsibility with respect to the ICR program is to:

a. Monitor controls with higher risk and greater vulnerabilities. b. Identify subject matter experts (SMEs) for each program, process, or procedure. c. Foster communication and develop a strategy to engage staff by aging the importance of internal controls. d. Track and address open GAO, TIGTA, and Financial Assurance Control Testing (FACT) audit ﬁndings and recommendations.
The ICR team develops a post

review report detailing methodology, testing, ﬁndings and recommendations, as appropriate. Internal Controls leadership delivers the report to the owner of the program being reviewed. The report may be provided to external stakeholders under certain circumstances. For example, reports and related materials will be provided upon request to TIGTA or GAO; reports may be provided auto
matically where the review is being conducted in conjunction with

Resource Guide for requirements of a larger audit process, such as the annual Campus Physical Security review performed in support of the GAO Financial Statement Audit. b. Findings may be reported to the Management Controls Executive Steering Committee (MC ESC) if the program is of sufficient scope and the control deﬁciencies discovered during the review are of sufficient ousness to warrant a broad leadership discussion. c. General, aggregated results of reviews performed during the year will used to support the IRS’s annual assurance statement. d. Results of reviews may be used to support the development of tion plans where control deﬁciencies are signiﬁcant enough to warrant this approach. (

) Qualitative evaluation of this program’s effectiveness is determined by: a. Whether business units report successful completion of corrective related to the ICR team’s recommendations. b. Whether business units implement new controls or measures based on ICR’s reviews. c. When applicable, how external stakeholders such as TIGTA and GAO use or interpret the ﬁndings and recommendations of the ICR team and whether they ﬁnd the analysis and recommendations thoughtful, and comprehensive. d. Whether TIGTA or GAO identify other ﬁndings not identiﬁed by the ICR team during its reviews. (
) An employee’s access to the ICR Shar
oint site is removed when an employee is no longer assigned to ICR. The site is protected by limiting to those individuals who perform the reviews and manage the program. (
) Final reports are provided to the program owner upon completion of the review. Request for additional distribution by the program owner is based on speciﬁc requests from stakeholders. (

) The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Internal Control - Internal control, which is synonymous with manage- ment control, is a major part of managing an organization. It comprises the plans, methods and procedures used to meet missions, goals, and objectives and in doing so, supports performance-based management. also serves as the ﬁrst line of defense in safeguarding assets and pre- venting and detecting errors and fraud. It helps government program managers achieve desired results through effective stewardship of resources. Internal control systems provide reasonable assurance to achieve effectiveness and efficiency of operations, reliability of ﬁnancial reporting and compliance with applicable laws and regulations. GAO’s Standards for Internal Control in the Federal Government (GAO-
G), page

, for a more comprehensive deﬁnition of internal b. Internal control review - An internal control review assesses internal controls by analyzing programs, policies and procedures and their effi- ciency and effectiveness. c. Internal Control Weakness - A ﬁnding labeled as an Internal Control Weakness occurs when testing reveals the overall system of internal controls is ineffective.

Final reports are provided to the program owner upon completion of the review. Request for additional distribution by the program owner is based on speciﬁc requests from stakeholders. The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Internal Control - Internal control, which is synonymous with manage- ment control, is a major part of managing an organization. It comprises the plans, methods and procedures used to meet missions, goals, and objectives and in doing so, supports performance-based management. It also serves as the ﬁrst line of defense in safeguarding assets and pre- venting and detecting errors and fraud. It helps government program managers achieve desired results through effective stewardship of public resources. Internal control systems provide reasonable assurance to achieve effectiveness and efficiency of operations, reliability of ﬁnancial reporting and compliance with applicable laws and regulations. Reference GAO’s Standards for Internal Control in the Federal Government (GAO-
G), page

, for a more comprehensive deﬁnition of internal control. b. Internal control review - An internal control review assesses internal controls by analyzing programs, policies and procedures and their effi- ciency and effectiveness. c. Internal Control Weakness - A ﬁnding labeled as an Internal Control Weakness occurs when testing reveals the overall system of internal controls is ineffective.
Management Information Only
A ﬁnding labeled as Management In
formation Only is designed to make management aware of a potential future issue which may arise if there are no improvements to controls. Opportunity for Improvement
A ﬁnding labeled as an Opportunity for Improvement occurs when one or more individual controls are but the overall system of controls is effective. Risk
A risk is an event or potential event that may negatively affect the achievement of a business objective. Risk assessment

A risk assessment is an evaluation of the potential hazards, threats, or opportunities which could affect an organization’s ability to conduct business. The reviews help to identify inherent risks and provide measures, processes, and controls to reduce or mitigate risks to business operations.

CR) process, which requests preliminary information from the business units pertaining to program internal controls in a focus area predetermined by the ICR program. ICRs, to include
CRs, are driven based on managerial interests, interests, IRS considerations, and congressional priorities, which deter- mines whether to initiate a full ICR or an

CR. b. The Annual Assurance process, which requests veriﬁcation of reviews the Quality Assurance Review (QAR) listing. c. Sampling of selected managers who completed the ICMA. d. New IRS initiatives the MC ESC or the Senior Executive Team has ﬁed. e. GAO and TIGTA audits identiﬁed as closed by Enterprise Audit Manage- ment (EAM).
Each ﬁscal year, the ICR team obtains a list of reviews the IC QAR and FACT teams are performing to eliminate any duplication of efforts by the ICR team.
The ICR program notiﬁes by email each business unit executive whose program has been selected for review by the ICR team.

Should reporting delays occur, ICR managers and the respective business managers will be notiﬁed by their subordinate staff. In the event a review is put on hold (either by ICR or the business unit), all participants will be of the hold, why the hold occurred and when the review will resume. Prior to initiating a program review, the ICR team will spend time getting to know and understand the program and the key program controls. The ICR team will use the following sources: a. A description of key processes, which includes examples of the ing documents (for example, ﬂowcharts, cycle memos and desk b. Policies and procedures governing transactions such as laws, regula

tions, IRMs, interim guidance memoranda, Servicewide Electronic Research Program (SERP) IRM procedural updates (IPUs), and operating procedures (SOP). c. External and internal reporting reviews (for example, reports issued by GAO or TIGTA). d. Congressional hearings or testimonies. The ICR team will use the information obtained to construct a framework and general review plan. This framework will outline the objectives and scope of the review and identify areas the review team will evaluate. However, it will also allow the review team the ﬂexibility to identify and pursue new leads or areas of signiﬁcant concern identiﬁed during the review. The framework and review plan will guide the overall review but should not constrain it. To conduct the review, the ICR team will: a. Conduct an opening conference with the POC or designated liaison. b. Request the POC provide contact information for the SME along with overview of the controls currently in place and how often management reviews the controls. c. Obtain procedural manuals from the POC and/or SME (for example, IRMs, SOPs and desktop/technical manuals) and back up from external audit sources (for example, internal examination reports and TIGTA or GAO audit reports). d. Request source documents such as raw data, transcripts, tax forms, and case ﬁles. e. Observe demonstrations of the program activity utilizing various media (for example, face
to
face and video technology) and transaction reporting. f. Conduct walkthrough procedures including a combination of inquiry, ob
servation, inspection of relevant documentation, and re

performance of controls. In performing a walkthrough, the ICR analyst will question personnel about their understanding of the prescribed procedures and controls involved in performing the daily work. g. Re
perform activities using source documents to check the procedural steps (for example, re

adding the total of a line of numbers to consistency). h. Evaluate the operating effectiveness of key internal controls. i. Conduct a closing conference at the end of the review with to discuss draft review ﬁndings and recommendations.

Resource Guide for (
) After the review, the team will analyze the data gathered and draft a report. The report will provide ﬁndings and/or recommendations identiﬁed during the review.Onc

CR leadership sends a report draft to an approval authority and the approval authority provides edits and feedback (within ﬁve business days), report author has a maximum of three business days to make any changes. Once the report author makes the changes, he or she will send report draft back to the appropriate approval authority. This step is as many times as needed until a report is released to the business unit. (

) The ICR analyst will share the report with the appropriate officials. If the ICR analyst noted ﬁndings during the review, the report will address the ﬁndings one of the following: a. Management Information Only (MIO) - Designed to make management aware of a potential future issue which may arise if there are no ments to controls. b. Opportunity for Improvement (OFI) - Occurs when one or more controls are ineffective, but the overall system of controls is effective. c. Internal Control Weakness (ICW) - Occurs when testing reveals the overall system of internal controls is ineffective. (
) Recommendations will follow the enumerated conclusions and opinions that are supported by the analysis. (
) The ICR analyst will submit all draft review reports for review, edits, and/or ﬁnal approval for the
CR and full ICR by completing Form
, Action Routing Slip. The draft report and Form
, Action Routing Slip, should submitted as follows: a.

CR - Respective ICR Section Chief and then the Director of Internal Reviews. b. ICR - Respective ICR Section Chief, Director of Internal Reviews, CFO Internal Controls, Executive Assistant, and then the Associate CFO for Internal Controls. c. For reviews with Deputy Commissioner or Commissioner-level informa- tion, ICRs will be approved by CFO. Anything requiring CFO approval be transmitted via e-Trak. (

) Each approving official will have ﬁve business days to review, edit, and/or approve the ﬁnal report. If edits are necessary, the approving official will back to the review report author for corrections. If no edits are warranted, approving official will sign Form
, Action Routing Slip, and send it back the review report author. (

) Business unit program owners and executives will receive a report from the ICR team describing the team’s ﬁndings and recommendations once the review is complete. ICR will provide recommendations to help business units identify areas where they should address control deﬁciencies and to provide general framework that business units may use for strengthening internal controls. Business units generally have one week to review the report and provide comments, which ICR will consider before issuing the ﬁnal report. (
) Business units should take the following steps once they receive the ICR team’s report: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
E

approving official will sign Form
, Action Routing Slip, and send it back to the review report author. (

) Business unit program owners and executives will receive a report from the ICR team describing the team’s ﬁndings and recommendations once the review is complete. ICR will provide recommendations to help business units to identify areas where they should address control deﬁciencies and to provide a general framework that business units may use for strengthening internal controls. Business units generally have one week to review the report and provide comments, which ICR will consider before issuing the ﬁnal report. (
) Business units should take the following steps once they receive the ICR
Program

a. Develop and implement corrective actions to address the ﬁndings and recommendations provided in the ﬁnal report. b. Assess and document the degree to which a control deﬁciency repre- sents a risk if the business unit(s) will not take corrective actions. c. Include any risks identiﬁed in the business unit’s risk register. d. Retain any documentation created as part of post-review corrective actions or risk documentation/mitigation activities. (

) The ICR team may conduct a follow-up engagement with the business unit ascertain the outcome of the steps described above. This follow-up ment may include review of the corrective actions and accompanying documentation by the business unit, or other steps up to and including a prehensive subsequent ICR. The timing and nature of any follow-up will depend on several factors, including the severity of control deﬁciencies, the nature of the program ICR reviewed and the likelihood external will subject the program to signiﬁcant scrutiny. (

) Business units should also consider these internal control improvement a. Reevaluate controls periodically, especially when there are changes personnel, work processes, business operations, and regulations may affect the business unit. b. Streamline monitoring processes to reduce burden and improve ability. c. Monitor and mitigate risk using data-driven approaches. d. Involve employees in identifying and mitigating risk. (

) Examples of control monitoring: a. Consider Disclosure/Privacy Act implications in all activities, including reviews of ﬁles and personnel folders. b. Perform risk reviews. c. Conduct quality assurance reviews. d. Initiate timely background and security investigations and take ate action based on the outcome of the investigation. e. Monitor telephone traffic volumes to ensure timely customer service. f. Review access to sensitive Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) command codes. g. Review assignment of portable electronic devices such as laptop computers, cellular/personal communications’ system devices, audio/ video/data recording or playback devices, scanning devices, and messaging devices to ensure safeguarding of these devices and the they contain and/or to ensure the employees who possess them still a business need for them. (
) ICR maintains its reports on the ICR Shar
oint site.
Develop and implement corrective actions to address the ﬁndings and recommendations provided in the ﬁnal report. Assess and document the degree to which a control deﬁciency repre
sents a risk if the business unit(s) will not take corrective actions. Include any risks identiﬁed in the business unit’s risk register. Retain any documentation created as part of post
review corrective actions or risk documentation/mitigation activities.

Consider Disclosure/Privacy Act implications in all activities, including reviews of ﬁles and personnel folders. Perform risk reviews. Conduct quality assurance reviews. Initiate timely background and security investigations and take ate action based on the outcome of the investigation. Monitor telephone traffic volumes to ensure timely customer service. Review access to sensitive Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) command codes. Review assignment of portable electronic devices such as laptop computers, cellular/personal communications’ system devices, audio/ video/data recording or playback devices, scanning devices, and messaging devices to ensure safeguarding of these devices and the they contain and/or to ensure the employees who possess them still a business need for them.
